issue.title: Fix spacing in command list and add edit command to command list
issue.body:
There was a tab for the start, stop, and copy commands that would cause `mux help` and autocomplete to have the command descriptions not line up properly. 

Also, since there was no `edit` command displayed, it wouldn't appear when using autocomplete.

Closes #415.

issue.title: `.tmuxinator.yml` in ./ overrides mux basic functionality
issue.body:
If you put a `.tmuxinator.yml` in the current directory you cannot use `mux help` or other commands instead tmuxinator auto-starts and/or attaches to the session defined in the local config.

version 0.7.0 (in Ubuntu 16.04 LTS)

issue.title: `.tmuxinator.yml` in ./ overrides mux basic functionality

issue.title: Strange behaviour when panes defined as multi-element dictionaries
issue.body:
There appears to be a bug in the handling of a pane element that contains a multi-element dictionary.  I found it when working on a PR for #266.

```yaml
# This works: A pane with 2 elements in an array, each being a single-element dictionary
panes:
  - pane1: echo "first pane"
  - pane2: echo "second pane"
# results in the expected 2 panes, each running its respective echo command.
```

```yaml
# This doesn't: An array that contains a multi-element dictionary
panes:
  - pane1: echo "first pane"
    pane2: echo "second pane"
# bizarrely creates three panes
# All the commands run in the first pane, the next two panes are empty panes
```

The options I see are:
1. Take the first element and ignore the rest (this is consistent with how multi-element Windows yaml is handled (`value = window_yaml.values.first` in window.rb:18)
2. Make each element its own pane
3. Print out some sort of invalid format error

I know its a corner case that's pretty minor, but I'm trying clean up the surrounding code a bit while I address #266.

Any thoughts?  I'm open to any suggestions.

issue.title: Strange behaviour when panes defined as multi-element dictionaries
issue.body:
There appears to be a bug in the handling of a pane element that contains a multi-element dictionary.  I found it when working on a PR for #266.

```yaml
# This works: A pane with 2 elements in an array, each being a single-element dictionary
panes:
  - pane1: echo "first pane"
  - pane2: echo "second pane"
# results in the expected 2 panes, each running its respective echo command.
```

```yaml
# This doesn't: An array that contains a multi-element dictionary
panes:
  - pane1: echo "first pane"
    pane2: echo "second pane"
# bizarrely creates three panes
# All the commands run in the first pane, the next two panes are empty panes
```

The options I see are:
1. Take the first element and ignore the rest (this is consistent with how multi-element Windows yaml is handled (`value = window_yaml.values.first` in window.rb:18)
2. Make each element its own pane
3. Print out some sort of invalid format error

I know its a corner case that's pretty minor, but I'm trying clean up the surrounding code a bit while I address #266.

Any thoughts?  I'm open to any suggestions.

issue.title: Fix for windows without panes
issue.body:
Fixes #328

The simple idea is that the `commands` instance variable of the `Window` class would not be initialized under certain conditions. This change ensures that `commands` will always be initialized, defaulting to an empty array.

Kudos to @fikovnik for the fix.

comment.body:
Ok cool.  I can recreate now.

Looking through the code the duplication in dealing with commands in `Tmuxinator::Window` and `Tmuxinator::Pane` jumped out at me:

```ruby
#Tmuxinator::Window
def tmux_pre_window_command
  return unless project.pre_window

  "#{project.tmux} send-keys -t #{tmux_window_target} #{project.pre_window.shellescape} C-m"
end

#Tmuxinator::Pane
def tmux_pre_window_command
  return unless project.pre_window

  "#{project.tmux} send-keys -t #{tmux_window_and_pane_target} #{project.pre_window.shellescape} C-m"
end
```

Also, both have to know about command(s) to be run in the pane/window.  The duplication is really obvious when you look at `lib/assets/template.erb`:
```ruby
# Window "<%= window.name %>"
unless window.panes?
  if window.project.pre_window
    window.tmux_pre_window_command
  end
  window.commands.each do |command|
    command
  end
else
  window.panes.each do |pane|
    if pane.project.pre_window
      pane.tmux_pre_window_command
    end
    pane.commands.each do |command|
      pane.tmux_main_command(command)
    end
  end
end
```

We shouldn't have the concept of a window without any panes.  In that case, we should just create a backing pane object and pass any window commands down to it.

Your fix works for the issue at hand though and it looks good to me.  Did you want to squash still or should I go ahead and merge?

commits.message:
Add new "rake test" task

I required RSpec's rake task file and loaded it, which gives access to
the `rake spec` command to run RSpec. Also, I added `rake test` which
will run `rake spec` and `rake rubocop`, to simplify testing.
Configure Travis CI to use "rake test"

Suggest contributors use 'rake test'

Added a note to the contributing guidelines suggesting that
contributors use 'rake test'.

Fix for Travis

I had mistakenly written `bundle exec test` instead of `bundle exec rake
test`

Updated "has-session" check to only match _exact_ session names.

 - removed previous test checking old behaviour.  Todo: Add new test?

Added dead-code elimination to template rendering

No longer include window/pane generation code if tmux session already exists
Fixed RuboCop code convention failures.
Removed Hound tasks
Fixed has_session method to return expected value.
Added tests

Merge pull request #404 from Richard-Walton/master

Updated "has session" check
#390 - fix local project deletion
#390 - change single-quotes to double-quotes to satiate RuboCop
#390 - updating CHANGELOG.md

Merge pull request #394 from ethagnawl/fix-local-project-deletion-redux

#390 - fix local project deletion

Merge pull request #399 from J3RN/rake-test

Add "rake test" command

Improve bash/zsh completion-setup flexibility

By removing the `tmuxinator`-existence checks and by employing the
correct completion definition functions, `tmuxinator.bash` and
`tmuxinator.zsh` can be sourced more flexibly, without running into
errors caused by not-yet-initialised `rvm` installations.

For `zsh`:

Previously, the first `#compdef` line was inserted to allow
`tmuxinator.zsh` to be used within `zsh`'s completion autoloading.
However, since it seems preferable to install `tmuxinator` completion by
directly sourcing files, this autoload-related definition is no longer
necessary, and an explicit `compdef` takes its place.

Merge pull request #400 from cinaeco/master

Improve bash/zsh completion-setup flexibility
Version bump to 0.8.0

Completions fix

The issue was that `puts` and `say` handle arrays differently. `puts`
will display each entry in the array on it's own line, but `say` will
spit out a formatted Ruby array. I rectified this issue by joining the
array with a newline, and use `say` to print it.

issue.title: 'mux start' not working: undefined method 'each' for nil:NilClass (NoMethodError)
issue.body:
I installed tmuxinator using 'sudo gem install tmuxinator', created a project and then attempted to start it. I get the following failure:

    $ mux start foo
      (erubis:41:in `block in render': undefined method `each' for nil:NilClass (NoMethodError)
            from (erubis:34:in `each'
            from (erubis:34:in `render'
            from /var/lib/gems/1.9.1/gems/erubis-2.7.0/lib/erubis/evaluator.rb:65:in `eval'
            from /var/lib/gems/1.9.1/gems/erubis-2.7.0/lib/erubis/evaluator.rb:65:in `result'
            from /var/lib/gems/1.9.1/gems/tmuxinator-0.6.11/lib/tmuxinator/project.rb:17:in `render'
            from /var/lib/gems/1.9.1/gems/tmuxinator-0.6.11/lib/tmuxinator/cli.rb:77:in `start'
            from /var/lib/gems/1.9.1/gems/thor-0.19.1/lib/thor/command.rb:27:in `run'
            from /var/lib/gems/1.9.1/gems/thor-0.19.1/lib/thor/invocation.rb:126:in `invoke_command'
            from /var/lib/gems/1.9.1/gems/thor-0.19.1/lib/thor.rb:359:in `dispatch'
            from /var/lib/gems/1.9.1/gems/thor-0.19.1/lib/thor/base.rb:440:in `start'
            from /var/lib/gems/1.9.1/gems/tmuxinator-0.6.11/bin/mux:18:in `<top (required)>'
            from /usr/local/bin/mux:23:in `load'
            from /usr/local/bin/mux:23:in `<main>'
    
    $ tmuxinator version
    tmuxinator 0.6.11
    $ tmuxinator doctor
    Checking if tmux is installed ==> Yes
    Checking if $EDITOR is set ==> Yes
    Checking if $SHELL is set ==> Yes
    $ tmux -V
    tmux 2.0

This is on Linux.
Please let me know which other information I can provide. 
I did not find any similar issues, so there must be something wrong in my installation.

comment.body:
@cwhits @madAndroid @jusw85 

Can you all report what version of tmuxinator you were using when you got this error?

issue.title: Fix for windows without panes
issue.body:
Fixes #328

The simple idea is that the `commands` instance variable of the `Window` class would not be initialized under certain conditions. This change ensures that `commands` will always be initialized, defaulting to an empty array.

Kudos to @fikovnik for the fix.

comment.body:
@J3RN I can't recreate the issue people have been complaining about.

In looking at the code, I think that the template iterates over the panes collection if they exist and only if they do not iterates over the commands collection.

```
    <% unless window.panes? %>
      ... 
      <% window.commands.each do |command| %>
  <%= command %>
      <% end %>
    <% else %>
      <% window.panes.each do |pane| %>
      ...
      <% end %>
   <% end %>
```

So even if `@commands` is not initialized, I don't see how that would cause it to blow up.  Have you been able to recreate the issue?

issue.title: Introduce Analytics Module
issue.body:
Per [#426](https://github.com/tmuxinator/tmuxinator/pull/426#issuecomment-223695238), I'd like to start a conversation about introducing an opt-in analytics module.

Open questions:

1. how will data be communicated/persisted? (e.g. Net::HTTP => Firebase)
2. how will the opt-in feature fit into to the Gem installation workflow?
3. what information should be captured? (e.g. Tmux version, OS, OS version, misc. usage, etc.)

comment.body: @Soliah Yeah I agree that looks nice.  Sounds good to me.  Just wanted to make sure we at least discussed the options.

issue.title: Introduce Analytics Module
issue.body:
Per [#426](https://github.com/tmuxinator/tmuxinator/pull/426#issuecomment-223695238), I'd like to start a conversation about introducing an opt-in analytics module.

Open questions:

1. how will data be communicated/persisted? (e.g. Net::HTTP => Firebase)
2. how will the opt-in feature fit into to the Gem installation workflow?
3. what information should be captured? (e.g. Tmux version, OS, OS version, misc. usage, etc.)

comment.body:
How about an opt-out instead?

I'm concerned about how many users would go out of their way to opt-in and question the value if we only get data from a small fraction of our user base.

An obvious, informative post-install message and frictionless opt-out seems like a reasonable approach (something like `mux optout`).  

I bounced the idea around with some coworkers (all tmuxinator users) and they all thought opt-out is totally reasonable if the messaging is clear.

Thoughts?  Would this be perceived as too obtrusive or invasive?

issue.title: Improve wemux support and clean up code
issue.body:
What is the state of our wemux support?

`lib/templates/wemux_template.erb` and `lib/templates/template.erb` have diverged quite a bit.  It would be nice to make the wemux template support the same features as tmux and then to pull everything that's common to a central place.

I've not used wemux much myself, I just don't like the duplication and divergence in the two templates.  If there are features wemux doesn't support this would be more difficult obviously.

Thoughts?

comment.body:
Exactly what I was thinking.  It almost feels like the example from chapter 1 of Fowlers Refactoring.  Form template method could work like Fowler used, but erb partials seems like a perfect solution.



Sent from my iPhone
> On Jun 3, 2016, at 8:25 AM, Jonathan Arnett <notifications@github.com> wrote:
> 
> I absolutely agree. Since it's ERB, could we use partials for common features?
> 
> ‚Äî
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.
>

issue.title: Add tmuxinator option to specify startup_pane.
issue.body:
Fixes #380

Before this change it was only possible to select the startup_window.
This change introduces an additional option 'startup_pane'. It can be
used to select the pane of the selected window on startup. The index
uses 0...x. Consequenty only panes of the selected window
('startup_window') can be specified.

I've not used wemux much myself, I just don't like the duplication and divergence in the two templates.  If there are features wemux doesn't support this would be more difficult obviously.

issue.title: BunnyMock::Queue#pop api does not match Bunny::Queue#pop
issue.body:
I see that BunnyMock::Queue#pop returns a hash with `:message` and `:options` keys:
```ruby
xchg.publish("Hello, everybody!", :routing_key => 'test1')

message = q.pop
message[:message]    # => 'Hello, everybody!'
message[:options]    # => { routing_key: 'test1' }
```

However Bunny::Queue#pop returns a 3 element array:
```ruby
xchg.publish("Hello, everybody!", :routing_key => 'test1')

delivery_info, properties, payload = q.pop
```

I assume that this was to make popping messages off of queues in specs a lot cleaner.  However, it makes BunnyMock only really able to help test the publishing of messages.  Any code that attempts to use Bunny to read messages from queues would not be able to use `BunnyMock.new` as a replacement for `Bunny.new`.

Ideally the APIs would match, however changing it would break anyone using the current behavior. I propose creating some sort of config option (e.g. `BunnyMock.use_bunny_queue_pop_api = true`) that could default to the current behavior.  The README could clearly show how to use the two options.

Thoughts?  Let me know if I'm misunderstanding something.  

I'll put together a PR if you're open to the idea.

comment.body: Awesome.  I haven't had a chance to look at this thoroughly yet, but thanks for being open to moving in this direction.

commits.message: fix typo in changelog
